content:
A hard salary cap and tricky playoffs prevent a runaway winner from dominating the competition

THIS YEAR’S edition of the Tampa Bay Lightning are the best team to take to the ice in the National Hockey League (NHL) for decades. On April 6th they concluded regular-season play with a typically convincing 6-3 victory over the Boston Bruins, the second-best team in the NHL’s Eastern Conference. It was the Lightning’s 62nd win this season, matching the league record set by the Detroit Red Wings in 1995-96, a squad that featured seven future members of the Hall of Fame. Tampa Bay had never before accumulated more than 54 victories in a season, and no NHL franchise in the last decade had won more than 56 games in a single campaign.

For a team to win more than three-quarters of its 82-game regular season fixtures, almost everything has to go right. For Tampa Bay this season, it did. Steven Stamkos, the veteran centre and captain, justified his annual $9.5m salary by commanding the league’s best offence. Meanwhile Nikita Kucherov, a winger, led the NHL in points (goals plus assists) and matched the all-time record for assists from his position. Andrei Vasilevskiy, the goaltender, remained one of the top puck-stoppers in the league, backing up a stellar defence which was led by Victor Hedman. Best of all, the Lightning remained largely injury-free. They scored 103 more goals than they allowed, while the next-best team, the Calgary Flames, managed a differential of only 62.

Every season features a leader in the wins column, but the structure of the NHL limits the likelihood that a team would dominate to such a degree. The league’s hard salary cap, introduced after a protracted labour dispute that wiped out the 2004-05 season, ensures that no team can simply spend its way to glory. A modest payroll limit, tied to league-wide revenues and set at $79.5m in 2018-19, keeps most free-agent salaries within reach of small-market clubs. When Detroit recorded their 62-win season 23 years ago, their $28.5m payroll was more than double that of four other teams, including the Lightning, who were still floundering as a recent expansion franchise. This year, all but two NHL teams spent at least $67m , within $11m of Tampa Bay’s $78m outlay.

Taking home the Presidents’ Trophy, the silverware given to the NHL team with the best record in the regular season, requires that those limited millions are spent wisely. Tampa Bay’s roster includes only one of the 25 highest-paid players in the league, Mr Stamkos, whose paycheck was tied for 15th place. Yet according to Point Shares (PS), a metric that apportions a team’s results among its players, the Lightning’s lineup is studded with skaters who were worth just as much. Leading the pack is Mr Kucherov, a 25-year-old right winger earning $5.5m, who posted one of the best offensive performances of the decade. His 14.6 PS set him comfortably ahead of Connor McDavid, Edmonton’s 22-year-old superstar, whose 13.0 PS was exchanged for a $15m paycheck. Wringing 62 wins out of $78m also requires that some production should come at next to no cost, such as the 11.4 PS earned by Brayden Point, the Lightning’s 23-year-old second-line centre. As a third-year player yet to qualify for free agency, Mr Point handed his team an all-star level performance for $650,000.

If the salary cap helps maintain regular-season parity, then the NHL playoff system has long served a similar purpose by preventing a runaway winner. To secure the Stanley Cup, the sport’s most coveted prize, a team must win four playoff rounds, each involving a best-of-seven-game series. In the 13 years of the salary cap era, the Presidents’ Trophy winners have emerged as overall champions only twice. None of the regular-season winners in the past three years—the Washington Capitals in 2015-16 and 2016-17 and the Nashville Predators in 2017-18—has even advanced past the second round. Using a simple model based on each team’s goals scored and allowed, the average favourite in a playoff head-to-head has a mere 63% chance of advancing. 

The 2018-19 Lightning are no average team. Yet the first day of the playoffs, on April 10th, served as a reminder that a short series in a low-scoring sport is never a sure thing. Tampa Bay’s path to the championship began with a 4-3 loss in their first game against the Columbus Blue Jackets, who squeaked into the playoffs as the second wild card in the Eastern Conference. In three head-to-head meetings this year, the Lightning not only won the lot, but also trounced the Blue Jackets by a combined score of 17 goals to 3. Nonetheless, Columbus, like every Eastern Conference team in the playoffs, is no pushover. The Blue Jackets added Matt Duchene and Ryan Dzingel, two veteran forwards, at the February trade deadline, and they boast one of the league’s strongest goaltenders in Sergei Bobrovsky. One series forecast that incorporated these roster additions, calculated before the surprising first-game result, gave the underdogs a one-in-four chance of progressing to the next round.

Even if there were a 75% probability that the Lightning would win each of their four rounds, that would give them less than a one-in-three chance of lifting the Stanley Cup. Betting markets are harsher still, giving them just a one-in-four shot. Two analytics-based models, published by Dom Luszczyszyn of The Athletic  and Neil Greenberg of the Washington Post , push that number down to one-in-five. Mr Greenberg’s forecast goes so far as to slightly favor the Calgary Flames to win the championship, as their Western Conference path to the final is likely to pit them against weaker opponents than the ones the Lightning must face.

The salary cap limits the effect of market size on team performance, and the NHL playoff structure counter-balances talent with a hefty dose of luck. The Lightning may not hoist the Stanley Cup this year, but most of the squad’s core is under contract well into the next decade, with Mr Kucherov signed until 2025 and Mr Stamkos until 2024. Should they falter in this year’s playoffs, they can take heart from the fate of the Red Wings 1995-96, who fell to the Colorado Avalanche in the conference finals. Neither the 1996-97 and 1997-98 editions of the Red Wings even won their regular-season division, but both accomplished what the 62-win squad could not, by winning the Stanley Cup. Next year’s post-season will offer its own share of obstacles, but Tampa Bay is well positioned to qualify for another bite at the cherry.

If you feel acute soreness or have lingereing fatigue, progress to the next week's training only when you can comfortably complete the preceding week's goal.

ex: v. 收缩；订约；感染
n. 【法】合同；〈非正式〉买凶杀人
网络 契约；合约；婚约
eg2: a contract of employment
雇用合同
a research contract
从事研究的合同
to enter into/make/sign a contract with the supplier
与供应商签订合同
These clauses form part of the contract between buyer and seller.
这些条款构成买卖双方所签合同的一部分。
a contract for the supply of vehicles
提供车辆的合约
to win/be awarded a contract to build a new school
获得承建一所新学校的合同
a contract worker(= one employed on a contract for a fixed period of time)
合同工
I was on a three-year contract that expired last week.
我签订的三年期合同已于上周期满。
Under the terms of the contract the job should have been finished yesterday.
根据合同的条款，这项工作本应于昨天完成。
She is under contract to(= has a contract to work for) a major American computer firm.
她已签约为一家大型美国计算机公司工作。
The offer has been accepted, subject to contract(= the agreement is not official until the contract is signed) .
此报价已获接受，尚须以签约为准。
They were sued for breach of contract(= not keeping to a contract) .
他们被指控违约。
to take out a contract on sb
雇凶手杀害某人
Glass contracts as it cools.
玻璃遇冷收缩。
a contracting market
萎缩的市场
The heart muscles contract to expel the blood.
心脏肌肉收缩以挤压出血液。
The exercise consists of stretching and contracting the leg muscles.
此项训练包括伸展和收缩腿部肌肉。
‘I will’ and ‘I shall’ are usually contracted to ‘I'll’(= made shorter) .
I will 和 I shall 通常缩约为 I'll。
to contract AIDS/a virus/a disease
感染艾滋病╱病毒╱疾病
The player is contracted to play until August.
这位选手签约参加比赛到八月份。
Several computer engineers have been contracted to the finance department.

A poem he wrote entitled “Vermin” seems to be about his need, and reluctance, to elicit that “faint squeak of mortality” from some psychic mouse, which he couldn’t put his finger on.
他写过一首诗，名为“害虫”，讲的似乎就是他本应该把手指放在那只想象的老鼠身上、挤出一声“轻微的临死前的呻吟”，但又不愿做这样的事情。
If you step on a nest, you cause a disaster — there's all kinds of cave-ins — and the ants that are buried signal with a little  that they need to be dug up.
如果你踩到蚁巢上，就引发一场各种大塌方的灾难。 那些被埋的蚂蚁会发出一种吱吱声，送信号给其他蚂蚁，说她们需要被挖出来。

Prices go up and they go down, but give stocks enough time and they deliver returns that  those of bonds, real estate, commodities or any other asset class.

Title: Why the NHL’s best team in decades is unlikely to win the Stanley Cup

paperStatistics.title: Why the NHL’s best team in decades is unlikely to win the Stanley Cup
paperStatistics.desc: A hard salary cap and tricky playoffs prevent a runaway winner from dominating the competition
